While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: to buys grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Poeng

texts.en: Poeng L. is a 37-year-old village woman who has had a job selling earthworms since she was single. Her husband is a local fisherman (pictured). The humble couple has two children; one is enrolled public school, one works in garment workerand has a regular salary per month. Currently, she also sells fresh fish and earthworms with her husband to wholesale and other fisherman for profit. This couple runs their business in the market and is earning approximately 5 a day. In addition, Poeng L. also planted rice two months ago, but her crops are not growing well. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer and the remainder to buy seeds for planting her farmland.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizer and the remainder to buy seeds.

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi C. lives in Bhaishipati, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family household with four members: herself, her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Bishnu C., is a driver. Her older son studies at the university and younger son is studying in grade 12.

Mrs. Laxmi C. started selling cows' milk three years ago. She already owns one cow. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 15,000.00 to buy another young cow to sell milk, because she lives in a growing neighborhood and in that area the demand for milk is increasing. In Nepal, people love to drink cows' milk so the demand for milk is increasing constantly.

loans.use: to buy a young cow

loans.name: Bhuma

texts.en:
This is 25 year-old Bhuma K..  She is married and has one child, aged 2.  In 2002, she established  her vegetable farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to purchase seeds and vegetables.  In the future, Bhuma plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support.   

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.  

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mujeres Rumbo Al Progreso Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Olinda es D. Huarochiri -  Chosica Perú, sus padres son ganaderos y como tal producen quesos, leche, mantequilla  y yogurt, ella comercializa estos productos los trae a lima para vender ya tiene dedicándose a eso mas D. 5 años con lo cual ha podido tener ingresos  que la han ayudado a salir adelante,  por otro lado también participa en un comedor D. madres en el barrio donD. vive, ella al igual que otras madres se dedican  a bordar y tejer para algunas empresas exportadoras, estos ingresos adicionales  son D. mucha ayuda para ella lamentablemente su esposo no tiene un trabajo fijo y así ella pueD. ayudar a costear los estudios D. su sobrina que esta a cargo D. ella y colaborar con la economía D. la casa el préstamo que EDAPROSPO le ha otorgado lo invertira en la compra D. sus productos lácteos para continuar con la venta D. ellos, Olinda intergra el  grupo “ MUJERES RUMBO AL PROGRESO” conformado por 8 socias ella tiene el cargo D. secretaria.

*Olinda es la octava D. la derecha esta con chompa D. coquitos ploma con negra.
texts.en:
Olinda is from Huarochiri - Chosica Perú.  Her parents are ranchers and, as such, produce cheeses, milk, butter and yogurt.  She sells these products by bringing them to Lima.  She has been in this line of business for 5 years, and it has allowed her to generate income to get ahead.  On the other hand, she also works with a group of mothers in the neighborhood where she lives.  She, along with the other mothers, do embroidery and knitting for some export companies.  The additional income from this activity is very helpful as her husband, unfortunately, does not have steady work.  Her income allows her to help with the educational expenses for her niece, who is under her care, as well as to cover the household’s needs.  She will invest the loan granted by EDAPROSPO into buying dairy products so she can continue to sell them.  Olinda is a member of the group “WOMEN HEADED FOR PROGRESS”, comprised of 8 members, and in which she serves as secretary.

* Olinda is the eighth woman counting to the right, wearing the black sweater with gray designs.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of cheeses, yogurt, and other products.

loans.name: Mao's Group

texts.en:
This loan group is made up of five members, who are shown in the picture. The group leader, Mrs. Mao K., is a 32-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Chhnang Province. She is married to Oum Sok, age 44. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has given birth to five children. One of the children is married and four are single. She and her husband also fish along the river in order to earn extra profit. As she lacks money to buy fishing gear and supplies, she has decided to request a loan from Kiva, and she will use these funds to buy nets and traps for the fishing business.

The other four borrowers:
Mrs. N. is asking for a loan to buying fishing equipment for earning extra profit.
Mrs. Y. is asking for a loan to purchase nets and traps.  
Mrs. E. is applying for a loan to buy fishing tools for additional revenue.   
Mrs. T. is applying for a loan to buy nets and traps for extra income.

loans.use: To buy nets, traps for fishing business.

loans.name: Goma

texts.en:
This is 52-year-old Goma K..  She is married and has three children, aged 26, 22 and 17.  In 1998, she established her cow-raising business.  Working 7 days a week and 5 hours a day, she supports her family. In the future, Goma plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks.  

The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.  This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering micro-credit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  

For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: to buy a young cow

loans.name: Chhany

texts.en:
Mr. Chhany Y. is 34 years old and his wife, Mrs. Saret Ouch, is 35 years old.  They live along national road number one, about thirty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1993 and had two sons. Unfortunately, one of them died.  The other one is in school.  

Chhany is a policeman. His wife stays at home and does house work. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to renovate the house where he lives.   

Mr. Chhany Y. was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To renovate his house

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
Mr. Sophorn P. and his wife, Mrs. Soklim Sim, have been married since 2001 and have one daughter (pictured) who is still young. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh approximately 25 kilometers outside of the city.

Mr. Sophorn P. has been a construction worker for more than twelve years. His wife has been a garment factory worker for more than eight years. Sophorn has previously asked for a Kiva loan.  Now he is seeking another loan of $800 to purchase a motorcycle to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Nopal

texts.en:
Mrs. Nopal M. is 49 years old and her husband, Mr. Salas Ly, is 55 years old.  THey have been married since 1980 and have five children:  one son and four daughters. They live along National Road number five about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Nopal sells water pans, knives, cutting boards, ladles and spoons at the market. Her husband sells silk fabric, which he buys in Phnom Penh and transports to sell in other districts far from home. 

Nopal is applying for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to carry silk fabric for resale. Because he does not have his own transportation, he currently spends a lot of money on  travel expenses.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport goods

loans.name: Ma-At

texts.en:
Mr. Ma-at E., 39, and his wife, Mrs. Sreyfas Mat, 35, have been married since 1990 and have four children - three sons and one daughter. The family lives along National Road Number Six about 20 Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Ma-at is a fisherman whose fish are sold by his wife at the village market. Because some of his fishing nets are broken, he is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase new nets and a boat motor so that he can continue his business.

Mr. Ma-at E. was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets and a motor for his fishing boats.

loans.name: Rohimas

texts.en:
Mrs. Rohimas M. and her husband, Mr. Ly Him, live along National Road Number Six about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Married since 1993, they have three children - two sons and one daughter.

Rohimas and her husband fish from the Mekong River for a living, selling their catches in the local market. The couple wants to purchase additional materials in order to increase the amount of fish they catch. Rohimas is therefore requesting a loan of $500 to make the purchases.

loans.use: To buy additional fishing materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Unidas Para Alcanzar El Exito Group

texts.es:
Carmen tiene 30 años, trabaja en el área de limpieza para la municipalidad de su distrito, con el fruto de sus ahorros y mucho trabajo ha podido comprarse una moto taxi (medio de transporte muy usado en Perú)  este vehiculo lo alquila y  le genera  ingresos diarios  a pesar que no es mucho dinero  es otra entrada que ella tiene, lo que quiere hacer mas adelante es vender la moto y con sus ahorros quiere comprarse un terreno construirlo poco a poco para poner su  propio negocio una jugeria  algo que conoce muy bien ya que antes ha trabajado en dicho negocio, el dinero de su préstamo lo utilizara para hacer un mantenimiento general a su moto para tenerla operativa y seguir haciéndola trabajar el grupo al cual pertenece es nuevo le han puesto como nombre “UNIDAS PARA ALCANZAR EL ÉXITO” nombre que las 8 socias han escogido por que se identifican de esa manera.

*Carmen esta sentada abrasando a la niña.
texts.en:
Carmen is 30 years old and works in the area of cleaning for the municipality of her district.  With her savings, and a great deal of hard work, she has been able to buy herself a moto taxi (a popular means of transportation in Perú).  She rents this vehicle, which generates daily income for her.  Although it’s not a lot of money, it’s another tool for her to make a living with.  What she would like to do in the future is sell the moto and use her savings to buy a plot of land to start her own juice business.  She knows this type of enterprise well, since she has previous experience in it.  

She will use the money from her loan to do general maintenance on her moto, in order to keep it operating and continue working.  She belongs to a group that has called itself “UNITED FOR SUCCESS”, a name chosen by the 8 women members because they can identify with it.

* Carmen is seated, holding the little girl.

loans.use: To maintain her moto-taxi.

loans.name: Tol

texts.en:
Mr. Tol S. and his wife, Mrs. Saros Sen, married since 1983, have six children: four sons and two daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Tol and his wife fish for a living from the Mekong River and the lakes near the village, selling their catches in the village market. Having received Kiva loans several times already, Tol is now requesting a new loan of $600 to purchase a boat motor.

Tol was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a boat motor.

loans.name: Muniran's Group

texts.en:
Muniran is a resident of Arifwala, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its dairy industry. She lives in the housing colony named Al-Badar, in a two-room brick house with her family. 

She is 39 years of age and a widow who lost her husband a few years ago as the result of a sudden death. She survived that time with great difficulty, but she recovered her senses and started a grocery store adjacent to her home to fulfill the basic needs of her family. 

Recently she has started another business of selling clothes. She purchases the clothes from wholesale markets in different cities such as Lahore and Faisalabad and sells to her local area clients. She has five children, three daughters and two sons. All of them are attending school and studying in different classes. 

Muniran has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her grocery shop business. With the loan, she will buy groceries in bulk quantities and increase her sales. She is confident that her business will grow further after making this loan investment. 

She is a regular user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Muniran.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros S. and her husband, Mr. Chantha Meach, both 52 years old, have been married since 1979 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home; one is a teacher; two attend school and another one assists her mother in the business. The family lives in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Ros and her husband, who sell rice and food at their home, now want to expand their business, so Ros is requesting a loan of US$600. She will use part of the loan to replace the motorbike her children drive to school because it is old and prone to mechanical problems.

loans.use: To expand her business and replace the motorbike her children use to drive to school.

loans.name: Nat

texts.en:
Mrs. Nat Y., 53, is a widow with two sons and two daughters. Two of them are married, while the other two are in school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Nat sells onsorm, a type of Cambodian cake that has rice and coconut with soybean and pork in the middle. As well, she also grows rice on her farmland in the village, assisted by her children. Nat is requesting her first loan of $400 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm and pay for ploughing fees.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun R., 48, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Seng, 50, have been married since 1984 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the family home; one is a garment factory worker, while the other two attend school. They family lives in a village along National Road Number Five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Saroeun has been operating a business producing bath mats for five months. Her husband is a motor taxi driver, but because his motorbike is old and requires frequent expensive repairs, she is requesting a loan of $300 to replace it.

loans.use: To buy a replacement motorcycle for her husband

loans.name: Vanky

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanky V. (in the photo with her loom), 30, and her husband, Sokha Toek, 37, have been married since 1998. They have three children -- one son and two daughters. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Vanky V. is a silk weaver. Her husband is a construction worker.  She is requesting her first loan of US$1,200 to purchase weaving materials (raw silk) for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials (raw silk) for her weaving business.

loans.name: Theary

texts.en:
Mrs. Theary N. is 25 years old and her husband, Mr. Bunthorn Phann is 55 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two children -- one son and one daughter. 

Mrs. Theary N. has been raising pigs for a year. Her husband has been driving a Tuk Tuk for five years. She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase additional piglets to raise. 

Photo: Theary is standing in front of her pigpen.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Sinat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinat S. (pictured above) is 42 years old and her husband, Mr. Sarat Vat, is 48 years old. They live on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1991 and have two children -- one son and one daughter. The son is a driver and the daughter has full-time employment.   

Mrs. Sinat sells clothes in Phnom Penh market. Her husband assists his wife in the business. He hopes establish a business selling meatballs, but he does not have capital. Hence Sinat is asking for a loan of $500 to provide capital for her husband.  

Sinat’s husband will use the loan to buy a motorbike to carry meatballs for sale.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to carry meatballs for sale.

loans.name: Anweri's Group

texts.en:
Anweri is a resident of Arifwala, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its dairy industry. She lives there with her family in a two-room brick house. She is married to G. M. and has no children.
 
She is a very talented lady who owns and operates her embroidery business at home. Earlier, she did this work to spend her time but later on she took it as a profession and now works on orders which she receives from different shops and from neighboring areas. She enjoys doing this work and earns well from it. Her earnings allow her to share the financial burden with her husband who operates a ready-made garment-selling business. 

Her husband has been dealing with his garment business for the last ten years. He has obtained a good reputation among his clients and serves them with quality clothes. He operates his shop in the market and deals with a good clientele base. 
 
Anweri has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy ready-made garments in bulk quantities for his business. The winter season has come and he will buy some winter clothes as well to provide a different variety to his customers. Anweri is hopeful that this investment will put more money in her husband’s pocket and his business will become more profitable for him. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy ready-made garments for reselling

loans.name: Lim-Ang

texts.en:
Miss. Lim-ang S. (in the photo), 36, is single. She lives with her parents and brother and sister in a village along National Road Number six, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Lim-ang works in a village office. She is asking for a loan of $300 to help provide capital for her brother, who is a farmer. He grows bananas and jujube.

loans.use: To provide capital for her brother’s farming business.

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
Sorm O., age 45, is married to Mr. Rin, age 46. She has two children, both of whom are employed as garment workers. Sorm O. is a local farmer in the province of Kompong Cham. She owns some farmland that she inherited from her grandmother many years ago. She planted some potatoes on her farm in order to add more income to support her family's needs. 

She has a life partner in her husband, who works in the construction field and earns approximately $2 per day. Currently, she intends to feed a few pigs for added profits, but she doesn’t have enough money yet. To solve this problem, Sorm O. would like to request a loan to buy more pigs for feeding. She proposes to use the remainder of the loan to expand her potatoes business.

loans.use: To buy more pigs for feeding.

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat, a resident of Arifwala, located in Punjab and famous for its dairy industry, owns a four-room house in a housing colony named Al-Badar and lives there with her family. She has given birth to four sons and two daughters. Only two of them have managed to get educations due to financial constraints.

To help support the family, Mussarat works as a seamstress, a trade she learned from her mother before marriage. Due to the quality of her work, she receives orders regularly from her neigbors, completing the work with the sewing machine she has in her home. For the past 10 years her husband, S., has run a scrap business in the market, selling a variety of items including used papers and empty plastic bottles to factories and other scrap dealers, thereby generating income for the family.

Mussarat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy scrap in bulk quantity and improve his sales. Mussarat is hopeful that with the help of this loan, her husband will be able to make more profits and improve his business conditions.

A regular customer of Asasah, this is her third loan request. In previous loans, she responsibly paid her installments and attended all meetings.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en:
Kaneezi, a resident of Arifwala, located in Punjab and famous for its dairy industry, is the mother of four sons and two daughters. Due to financial constraints, only three children are able to get an education. She is married to M. B., a school teacher earning a meager income. Kaneezi owns a three-room brick house in a housing colony named Al-Badar where she lives with her family. Her brother-in-law also lives with her family and works as a cobbler.

A seamstress, Kaneez works very hard to support her family financially as she sews clothes for her neighboring clients. She has been doing this work for over five years and has established a good reputation amongst her customers for providing good quality services.

Kaneez is now requesting a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother-in-law’s shoe making business. With the loan, he will buy required items such as nails, leather and shoe polishers, items that will enable him to make more shoes and earn additional pprofit. He has been engaged in this business for over 15 years, and Kaneez is confident that his business will grow with the help of this investment.

A regular loan user of Asasah, this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended all meetings.

Note: In the photo, the lady holding the book (called Asasah Passbook) is Kaneez.

loans.use: To buy items for shoe-making business

loans.name: Jovenes Emprendedores Group

texts.es:
Al empezar una nueva vida como casada Carmen vio la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo en la economía del hogar, ella quería vender algo pero no sabía que cosa, es así que por medio de sus sobrinas a quienes siempre observaba que compraban accesorios como ganchos, correas, vinchas. se le dio la idea de empezar a vender dichos productos, primero los ofrecía a sus conocidos  compraba y vendía toda clase de accesorios para jovencitas, también se las ingeniaba para copiar modelos de catálogos y venderlos mas baratos con mucho trabajo pudo consolidar su negocio ahora cuenta con mucha clientela y gracias a esto ha podido tener algunas comodidades como comprar algunos artefactos que hacían falta en su casa, pero lo que considera mas importante es ayudar en la educación de sus hijos, ahora esta pensando en dedicarse a la confección de ropa para mascotas ya que otras de sus pasiones es el tejido a mano ella confecciona ponchos, chalinas y ropas de baño, hace poco tejió algunas muestras,  un familiar lo llevo a los EEUU  ahora esta recibiendo pedidos es por eso que piensa incursionar en este nuevo negocio para lo que usara el  préstamo que EDAPROSPO le ha otorgado  piensa comprar hilos para dedicarse a este negocio que recién empieza y sabe que tendrá un buen futuro.

*La Sra. Carmen esta en medio de todas.
texts.en:
When starting out as a newlywed, Carmen recognized the need to help her husband financially in order to meet their household expenses.  She wanted to sell something, but wasn’t sure what.  By observing her nieces, who were always buying accessories such as pins, belts and barrettes, she got the idea to start selling these types of products.  She first started selling to her acquaintances, offering all types of accessories for young girls.  She also devised the idea to copy styles out of catalogs, and sell them at lower prices.  With a great deal of hard work, she was able to strengthen her business.  She now has a large customer base, and this has allowed her to buy some items that she needed for her house.  

However, she considers educating her children to be of utmost importance.  She is now thinking about making pet’s clothing, since another passion of hers is knitting.  She makes ponchos, scarves, and swimsuits.  Not long ago she knitted some samples that were taken to the U.S. by a relative, and she is now receiving orders for some of her items.  For this reason, she is thinking about starting this type of new business.  She plans to use the loan from EDAPROSPO to buy thread so she can dedicate herself to this business that she is just starting, and knows she has a bright future ahead.

* Carmen is in the middle of the group.

loans.use: To purchase thread to make pet's clothing.

loans.name: Chrouk

texts.en:
Chrouk N., age 41, and her husband, Hout Yan, age 61, earn a living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Chrouk N. also keeps ducks to produce eggs, and she sells the eggs to people who come to buy in bulk at her house. The couple has eight children, one of whom is married and seven of whom live at home. The family lives in Kompong Cham Province.

Chrouk N. has applied for a $700 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional feed and ducks to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional feed and ducks to raise

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a seamstress. She sews clothes for her neighbors and local clients in order to earn the money to help fulfill the basic needs of her family. She is married to G. N., who drives a three-wheeled rickshaw and provides transport services to his clients. They own and reside in a two-room brick house in a housing colony named Al-badar, located in Arifwala, which is a small city in Punjab that is famous for its dairy industry. They have two sons and three daughters.  

Kosar is a very caring mother and has raised her children very well. Due to poor financial conditions, she was only able to manage to provide for the education of her first three children, but she is hopeful that with the help of better income she will be able to send her remaining children to school as well. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to apply toward her husband’s business. The tires on the rickshaw are worn down and direly in need of replacement. With the loan, her husband will repair his rickshaw. Kosar is hopeful that with this loan investment her husband’s income will be improved and her family will be able to live in a better financial condition. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To repair the rickshaw and replace its tires

loans.name: Sarwari's Group

texts.en:
Sarwari is a vigorous lady who owns and operates an embroidery business at her home. She is engaged in this work because she enjoys it and also because she wants to share in alleviating the financial needs of her family. Both these motivations provide her with the courage and determination to perform her work well and to satisfy her customers' needs with new embroidery designs. She is very creative in her work, resulting in a good number of clients who admire her work and place orders regularly from her.
  
Sarwari has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to apply toward her husband's business. He runs a milk shop in the market where he provides his customers with fresh, high-quality milk and yogurt. With the help of this loan, he will buy milk and yogurt in larger quantities to sell in his shop. Sarwari is hopeful that her husband will get the maximum profit from his 12-year-old business with this loan investment.

The couple have two sons and three daughters and live in Arifwala, a small city located in Punjab and famous for its dairy industry. They own a two-room brick house in a housing colony named Al-badar. Due to their poor financial conditions, they could only provide for the education of their two eldest children, who are in the fifth and eighth grades. 
  
Sarwari is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she proved herself to be a responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed any meetings.
 
In the photo, Sarwari is the one holding a book (called the "Asasah Passbook") in her hands.

loans.use: To buy milk and yogurt to sell at market

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya, where he has been practicing mixed farming for five years. His mixed farm produces maize, which he sells locally, and tea, which he sells through the Kenya Tea Development Authority. He depends on the income from his farm to provide for the basic needs of his family. His biggest challenges have been unpredictable weather conditions and price fluctuations.

Joseph is 41 years old. He and his wife have been blessed with six children: the youngest is still a baby and the eldest is 15 years old. The four older children are currently attending school.

He has requested this loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children and that the dairy cow will be a source of milk to the family as well. 

In future, he would like to buy land that will enable him expand his dairy farming endeavors.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch B., age 54, lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Touch B. is a good mother of eight children, three of whom are school-aged while the remaining five are married and have a formal salary. 

Touch B. and her husband are rice farmers; additionally, Touch B. owns a few ponds in which she grows lotus flowers. Three months after planting, she harvests them to sell. She sells the lotus to people who need them for ceremonies to bless the gods. Right now, she hopes to plant new lotus, but she lacks funds for growing lotus. Therefore, Touch B. will use her loan for her lotus business. Any remainder of the loan she will use towards growing rice. Touch B. is  at her farm field in the photo.

loans.use: To expand her lotus business and for growing rice

loans.name: Hyline

texts.en:
Twenty-five-year-old Hyline is a married mother of 3 children who are now between the ages of 1 and 8. Two of the children are currently attending school. She is a dairy farmer from Nyamira town in western Kenya. She has been farming for 5 years and employs one farmhand. Her farm produces milk which she sells locally. She also earns income from her small-scale farming of tea which she sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority. She also operates a shop in the same area.

Hyline has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 40,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will go towards the education of her children. Her biggest challenges have been hailstones which destroy her tea and drought which affects her milk production. In future, she hopes to expand her farming and have a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Vuffie

texts.en:
Vuffie T. is from the town of Surallah. She is 34 years old. Vuffie is married and has three children. To make a living, Vuffie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruit & vegetables for sale. Vuffie also recently opened a small sari-sari store where she sells different kinds of products like sugar and vinegar.

Vuffie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vuffie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Vuffie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey has been practicing mixed farming for twelve years in the town of Nyamira in western Kenya. His farm produces milk, which he sells locally, and tea, which he sells through the Kenya Tea Development Authority. He also earns income from his employment at a local tea factory. His primary challenges are drought, the diseases that affect his crops and livestock, and poor road networks.

Geoffrey is 36 years old. He and his wife have five school-aged children, all of whom attend school.

He has requested this loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will go toward the education of his children and will improve the livelihood of his family. 

In future, he would like to expand his dairy and tea farming endeavors and also venture into maize farming. He would also like to be educated more on crop and livestock farming.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn S. is from the town of Surallah. She is 22 years old. Lovelyn is married and has 2 infant children. She is engaged in rice farming. She says the harvest from the farm helps her family a lot as they use it for consumption and sell the rest to the market. She was also able to acquire pigs that she is raising now. Lovelyn hopes for her business ventures to prosper.

Lovelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lovelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn M. is from the town of Surallah. She is 43 years old. Merlyn is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Merlyn also raises pigs for fattening and sale. 

Merlyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase a heating system which has a boiler and a stove

loans.name: Melindy

texts.en:
Melindy C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 47 years old. Melindy is married and has three children. She is a farmer and hog raiser. She plants and harvests rice crops. The pigs she raises are for fattening and sale. Melindy hopes her business will grow and give her family better income. 

Melindy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melindy is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed and farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Soronzonbold

texts.en: Soronzonbold B. is 44 years old and lives with his wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Soronzonbold operates a coal and wood transportation business in his town. He began this business in 2006 with working capital of 500,000 MNT. He usually purchases firewood and coal from Bulgan sub-province and sells to local individuals. The business is supported by his wife, and it has grown into a successful operation. Today, his working capital exceeds 2,300,000 MNT. His earnings have enabled him to build a new house and fence for his son. Soronzonbold is an honest and friendly man. He is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan for his coal and firewood transportation business.

loans.use: To purchase coal and firewood

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old and married. She has six children, the younger of whom still go to school. To make a living, Tessie raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. Tessie works hard to sustain her children's education.

Tessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Laurence

texts.en:
Laurence E. is from the town of Surallah. He is 34 years old. To make a living, Laurence owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Laurence also raises pigs for breeding. He works hard to help his family financially.

Laurence joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laurence has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Laurence is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm supplies and pig feed. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and pig feed.

loans.name: Aina's Group

texts.en:
Aina A. has the status of group’s leader. She is 41, married, and her family has 3 children; the eldest son is a student, the other 2 are school pupils. The family runs their own business, which is cattle breeding and dairy product sales. Eight years ago, they sold sugar and out of the profits bought a cow. Due to the business over the years, Aina has managed to give her son a university education and to increase cattle stock. The loan purpose is to purchase hay for cattle feed. In future, the family wants to arrange for the son’s wedding and to obtain a car.

Djoldoshbek M., 56, is married. His wife has a profession of medical assistant. The couple has 5 children. The family is engaged in cattle breeding and dairy product sales. The loan purpose is to purchase coal for winter.

Elmira K., 41, is married to a tractor driver. The couple has 6 children. The family has been breeding cattle and selling dairy products for 16 years. Their loan purpose is to purchase cattle to develop the business. 

Saule E., 41, is married. Her husband works in Bishkek, where he sells meat in the market. The couple is raising 3 children. With her husband’s and son’s help, Saule breeds cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a washing machine. 

Zainudin A., 36, is married. Her husband supports the family by working as a school teacher. The couple is raising a daughter. The family make their living by cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase calves for resale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hay for cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To complete his stock.

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida T. is the leader of the group. She is 33, married. Her husband is a herder, and raises 8000 soms per month. The couple has 5 children; the elder are school pupils, the younger are at home. The family is engaged in cattle breeding, they have been doing it for 16 years since 1994, when Farida’s husband, using the profits from selling apples, could afford to buy 4 sheep for breeding. Now, the family keeps 70 livestock animals and 3 cows. The loan purpose is to purchase more cattle. In future the family plans to build a new house.

Ilyas T., 32, is married. His family has 2 children; Ilyas supports his family financially by cattle breeding. The loan purpose is to purchase more farm animals. 

Nazira M., 35, is married. Her husband is a private taxi-driver. The couple is raising 4 children. Nazira is eganged in breeding livestock animals, and she hopes to obtain the loan in order to purchase 5 livestock animals. 

Kerimbai C., 42, is married, and has 3 children. In 2000, the family began to resell cattle in the local market. Kerimbai wants to use the loan to increase commodity circulation. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Nodira

texts.ru: Зохирова Нодира проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст, 31 год. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж в России на заработках. Сама Нодира имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии не работает. После замужества занималась домашним хозяйством и воспитанием детей. Сейчас она шьет национальные платья на заказ. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже один год. Кредит берет для закупа швейной машинки.
texts.en: Nodira Z. lives in the city of Dushanbe.  She is 31 years old, married and has 3 children.  Her husband works in Russia.  Nodira has a higher education, as an economist.  She does not work in her field.  After she got married, Nodira was involved in household work and raising the children.  Currently, she makes national dresses to-order.  She has been involved in this business for one year.  Nodira is requesting this loan for the purchase of a sewing machine.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a farmer from Nyamira town in western Kenya. She has been farming for ten years and has employed one farmhand. Her mixed farm produces tea, which she sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority, as well as maize, sorghum and bananas which she sells locally. She mainly depends on the income from her farm to provide for the basic needs of her family.

Josephine is 34 years old. She is married with 5 school-aged children who all attend school.

She has requested this loan of 45,000KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help in paying school fees for her children and improving the living standards of her family. She faces the challenge of diseases, which affects her crops and animals. In five years time, she plans to increase the number of her dairy cows to four and start a wholesale business.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Battsooj

texts.en:
Battsooj G. is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayanhoshuu of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. He and his family live in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest daughter attends a college and his youngest son currently attends a local high school. His wife is currently unemployed.

Battsooj operates a taxi service in his town. He started driving a taxi in 2000 and has been quite successful. His earnings have allowed him to start building a small shop in his yard and it will be operated by his wife. For the future, he plans to repair and enlarge his house where the family currently lives. Battsooj is a very honest man and is requesting a 350,000 MNT loan to repair his car.

loans.use: To repair his car.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mariambubu's Group

texts.en:
Mariambubu M. is the leader of the group. She is 38 and married to a farmer. Together they are raising four children. In order to make money Mariambubu works as a cleaner at school. She is also engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a calf in order to increase the number of cattle.
 
Gulzar A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 28 and married. She has four children. Gulzar and her husband are farmers. They make money by selling cattle and milk. With money received from the loan Gulzar wants to purchase a cow.

Nurbek K., 40, is married. He has three children. In order to earn money, Nurbek breeds livestock animals and his wife sells convenience goods in the shop. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase five sheep for breeding. 

Aidai K., 20, is married. She has a newborn child.  Aidai and her husband are farmers. They hope to obtain the loan because they need money to purchase 100 liters of fuel which is needed for cultivating the land.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf.

loans.name: Isroil

texts.ru: Сафаров Исроил проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 21 год. Холост. Образование среднее. Занимается перевозкой людей. Он в основном предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области уже год. Кредит берет для закупа автомашины. Он намерен продать свою старую машину и купить новую.
texts.en: Isroil S. lives in the city of Kulob.  He is 21 years old, single.  He has a secondary education.  Isroil is involved in passenger transportation.  He primarily provides taxi service.  Isroil has been in this business for one year.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of a car.  He intends to sell his current old car and buy a new one.

loans.use: Purchase of a car

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Janet has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Janet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Janet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Janet hopes to expand her business.

Janet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning more on how to handle business.

loans.use: To buy sugar.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Faridah has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Faridah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase soap and sugar. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Faridah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Faridah hopes to study and become a pilot.

Faridah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by always having educational discussions among themselves.

loans.use: To buy soap and sugar.

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.ru: Касимова Насиба жительница Вахдатского района. Возраст, 43 года. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Работает на рынке. Арендует торговую точку, где продает продукты питания. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 8 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Nasiba K. lives in the Vahdat district.  She is 43 years old, married and has 3 children.  She has a secondary education and works at a market.  Nasiba leases a retail outlet, where she sells food products.  She has been in this business for over 8 years.  She is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Nakyesa Widows And Aids Patients Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
N. Harriet, 32, is good-natured and full of energy. These attributes have won her awards in the running of her 12-year-old pharmacy business in Nakyesa-Kayunga. Her clinic is Yesu Amala Clinic.

Harriet also has a livestock rearing business.

To start this business, she had to use her salary savings. She was working as a health assistant before. She makes a profit of 50,000 shillings weekly. 

With this loan, this married mother of three wants to restock her pharmacy with more drugs to sell. She belongs to Nakyesa Widows and Aids Patients group-Kayunga.

loans.use: The purchase of more drugs for sale at her pharmacy

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Dulamsuren U. is a 41 year old single mother with a teenage daughter. She and her daughter live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter attends a high school and Dulamsuren operates a hair salon. She has been engaged this business since 2002 and has built a stable operation. She has been working as a hairdresser for almost 8 years. For the future, Dulamsuren hopes to expand her business and increase her working capital so that she can afford her daughter's tuition fees.

She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy more materials and supplies for her hair salon in order to increase her working capital, as well as to make repairs to her home.

loans.use: To make repairs to her home.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 1 child who is not currently in school. Grace has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for less than one year.         

To help expand her business, Grace has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Grace hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Grace hopes to build a house, and own a successful business.

Grace is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to save.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy N. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 1 child, who is not currently in school. Prossy has a business of a salon, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase braids. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Prossy hopes to own a cosmetics shop.

Prossy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning to be responsible.

loans.use: To buy braids.

loans.name: Katana

texts.en:
Katana is a married man with three girls; one attends school while the other two are still too young for school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

He has operated his restaurant business for the past three years, selling to his neighbours and passersby. Katana faces the major challenge of inadequate kitchen utensils to serve many customers. He hopes to operate a big restaurant serving many customers in the future. 

Katana decided to join Yehu because it provides sustainable financial services to social economically marginalized entrepreneurs. With the Kshs 15,000 loan, he wants to purchase kitchen utensils, spoons, and plates for his restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen utensils, spoons, and plates for his restaurant.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new laptop.

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida is a resident of Mughalpura, which is a small area located in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has lived there with her family in a 2 room brick house for the last 5 years. She is a seamstress by profession. She collects orders from her neighboring clients and provides them with the finished work in the given time period and earns income from it. She does this work to financially support her family.
  
Her husband is a private entrepreneur and has a fruit sales business. He buys seasonal fruits from the fruit wholesale market and sells them on different streets of the city by putting them on a four-wheeled cart. He has been doing this business for over 4 years and works very hard every day to earn good income for the family.
  
Shahida has given birth to 3 sons and a daughter. Her sons are studying in 6th, 2nd, and kindergarten respectively, while her daughter is just 1 year old. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal fruits for his business. Shahida is hopeful that this will help her husband to make more sales and more income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. She hopes that it will be a step towards more profits for her husband’s business. She is part of a group loan of four.

Note: “In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Shahida”.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal fruits for reselling.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy M. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 1 child, who is not currently in school. Mercy has a business of a salon, which she has had for 1 year, and she also sells cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Mercy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase cosmetic lotions. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mercy hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Mercy hopes to own a big cosmetics shop.

Mercy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to save.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic lotions.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Narantuya

texts.en:
Narantuya M. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter is a university student, while her husband is currently unemployed.

Narantuya manages a consumer goods trade business in her town. She sells a variety of consumer goods and items that are imported from China. Narantyua started her business in 2006 with capital of 600,000 MNT and has built a stable operation. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,300,000 MNT. Her earnings have enabled her to build a house in her yard. For the future, Narantuya hopes to expand her trading business by selling a variety of clothing items. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food and charcoal.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem belongs to Lahore, which is a capital of the Punjab province and the second largest city of Pakistan. She lives in the area called Mughalpura with her family in a two-room brick house. She moved here five years ago. 

A very talented lady, Naseem owns and operates a clothes sewing business at her home. The sewing business is a very demanding business in Lahore because Lahore is also famous for its new fashion trends. She mainly gets orders from her neighborhood clients. She offers them quality services, which gives her a good return in the form of money.
  
Her husband sells shawls (a kind of cloth worn over shoulders and body). He has a small shop in the market where he specifically sells these shawls. He sells different kinds of shawls, such as embroidered, simple and colorful. He imports the shawls from Multan city at cheap rates and sells them through his shop for a good profit.  

Naseem is the mother of six children. Her eldest son is a rickshaw driver and the one next to him is a property dealer. The last four children are enrolled in a school and are getting their education. 

Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. He will buy shawls with the loan amount. He has been doing this business for over seven years and Naseem is hopeful that the loan will bring positive changes to his business. 
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she built a good credit record and never missed any meetings.
  
Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy shawls for a shawls selling business

loans.name: Shima Ii Group

texts.fr:
Oda K. est une femme commerçante âgée de 53 ans qui habite au Quartier Buyenzi en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de produits d’habillement (habits et chaussures) au Marche Central de Bujumbura, un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 30ans. Au cours de ses années d’exercice de son metier, elle a ajoute les produits vivriers dans ses produits de commerce. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 10e année de l’école secondaire. Elle est veuve. Elle arrivait au 6e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame mais elle intègre maintenant le crédit solidaire. 

Elle est mère de 8enfants dont 4 ont déjà eu leur Diplôme et les 4 qui sont à l’école secondaire.
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  en achetant de grandes quantités de produits d’habillement et vivriers à revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Elle a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car elle a beaucoup de facilités à rembourser. 
 
Elle  est une des membres du groupe  solidaire« Shima II».
texts.en:
Oda K. is a 53-year-old shopkeeper who lives in the Buyenzi district of the Bujumbura mayorship. She sells clothing items (clothes and shoes) at the Bujumbura central market, a line of business she has been working in for 30 years. Over the years, she added food products to her product offer. She attended school until the tenth year of the secondary level. She is a widow. She is on her sixth cycle of group loans with Turame, but now also incorporates an individual loan. 

She is the mother of 8 children, of which 4 have already graduated and 4 attend secondary school.

She is requesting a Kiva loan to increase her capital by purchasing large quantities of clothing items and food products to sell to clients and thereby increase her savings. She preferred to ask for the loan from Turame because it will be easy for her to repay. 

She is one of the members of the « Shima II» solidarity group.

loans.use: To increase her capital by purchasing large quantities of clothing items and food products to sell to clients

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia M. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Scovia has a business of outside catering. She has been frying chapati (a flat bread) for a year.         

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase baking flour and cooking oil. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Scovia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  

In the future, Scovia hopes to expand her business. Sarah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her new games like ludo.

loans.use: Baking flour, cooking oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: He wants to complete his stock

loans.name: Sosorbaram

texts.en:
Sosorbaram D., age 34, lives with his wife and two sons in Tuv province, Mongolia. They have lived together in a 'ger' (traditional Mongolian tent home) on a small plot of land they own for several years. His two sons, ages 12 and 8, attend a local school while his wife works as a cook in a restaurant. 

Sosorbaram operates a meat trading business at Huchit Shonhor market, the largest meat supply market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has operated this business for the last 3 years and has found much success with his new business. He usually purchases his meats from the countryside and sells it at the Huchit Shonhor market as a wholesaler. Also he sells meat through meat shops in the rural areas as a retailer.  

Before starting his own business, he was a herder between 1992 and 2002 and worked as an assistant in the meat shop at the Har horin, a big market in the city from 2002 to 2004. His business was successful enough to purchase a new house and fence for his family. Moreover, his earnings have enabled him to buy a new small car as well as a van for his business. 

He is planning to establish his own meat processing factory in a building that he purchased out of his earnings. Sosorbaram is a very modest, honest and hard-working man. "My only goal is to open my own meat processing factory and export a variety of processed meats on the foreign market," he says. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan for his meat trading business.

loans.use: To buy more meat

loans.name: Hameeda's Group

texts.en:
Hameeda belongs to Lahore which is Pakistan’s second largest city and famous for its history. She has been living in a 2-room brick house in an area there named Mughalpura with her family for the past 9 years. She is 33 years old and operates her clothes selling business to share the financial burden with her husband. She has good number of customers in her neighborhood and earns good profit by selling them a variety of clothes. 

She is married to L. A. who operates a plant selling business. He operates a nursery (a place to display plants & flowers) from where he offers a variety of flowers and plants to customers. He has been doing this business for over 7 years and has a good knowledge of this business. 

Hameeda is the mother of three daughters and a son. All of them are studying except her son who is only 1 year old. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy a variety of plants and flowers to sell through his nursery. Hameeda is confident that her husband will successfully grow his business after this loan investment.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Hameeda.

loans.use: To buy plants & flowers for a nursery (a place to display plants & flowers)

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah A. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Sarah has a business of selling local beer, which she has had for three years.         

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase millet for brewing local  beer.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees, house rent, and food.  In the future, Sarah hopes to build a house.  Sarah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to work.

loans.use: millet for brewing local  beer

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with one child who attend school. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food.

She has operated her hardware shop and timber sale business for over five years, selling retail and at the market. Mary faces a major challenge of transportation. She purchases timber from rural areas and transports it to her place of work hence incurring costs. She hopes to own a big hardware shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 35,000 she wants to purchase a stock market timer machine, iron sheets for resale and pay for a business license. She decided to join Yehu to get loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a stock market timer machine, iron sheets for resale and a business license

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 42 years old, married with three children who are 7, 10 and 12 years old.  Martin has owned a motorcycle since 2008.  He starts driving from early in the morning and continues until late in the evening.  In other words, he works hard in order in order to get the basic needs for his family.

Martin needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a second motorcycle which will hopefully allow him to increase his income.  If successful, that is, if his income increases, he will improve the lifestyle of his family and in addition to that, he will try to create some other sources of income as well as creating jobs for people from his community.

loans.use: the purchase of a second motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 39-year-old married man and the father of 3 school-age children. He has been working as a mechanic for the past 20 years. In 2004, he opened his own car repair shop and he is specialized in repairing vehicle bodies. He has been a reliable client and repaid on his scheduled date. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase an air compressor in order to reinforce his business operation and further develop his work. He is looking to diversify his business and open a new shop where he can buy and sell spare car parts. His income is needed to help support his wife and three children.

loans.use: purchase an air compressor

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice Nakitto is 18 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is married and has no children. Alice has a garment shop business which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Alice hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Alice hopes to expand her business. Alice is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to save.

loans.use: clothes

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon S. is a 43-year-old woman, married to Mr. Vin Mao, age 47, and they are living in Battambang Province. Phon S. lives with three school-aged children and earns a living by planting various crops on their own farmland. Phon S. is currently planting a potato crop, which she will harvest and sell when they are mature. She has a life partner in her husband who works in motorcycle repair, earning approximately US$ 3 per day. This couple also takes time to fish around the river from which they are able to make additional income. 

Phon S. has hired a neighbor’s boat to support her in her fishing activities. She wants to be the owner of a boat which will allow her to cut out the hiring cost. In order to ensure that is possible, Phon S. would like to request a Kiva loan in the amount of US$ 400 to be used to buy a boat, as well as buying more fishing gear.

loans.use: To buy a boat, as well as buying more fishing gear

loans.name: Phylis

texts.en:
Phylis is a married woman with three children all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the family.

She has operated her business of selling second-hand clothes and natural juices for over five years; neighbours and passersby are her major customers. Phylis faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. During winter, the cold season, demand for heavy clothes is high compared to the hot summer season where demand is low for heavy clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase a bale of clothes and cooler boxes for storing natural juices for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of clothes and cooler boxes for storing natural juices for resale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is currently in school.  Mary has a salon business, which she has had for 4 years.  She also does brick laying.  

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase braids and paying the workers of brick laying.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Mary hopes to own a day care center.  Mary is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by expanding her business.

loans.use: braids and paying the workers for brick laying

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah has a mixed farm that produces milk and vegetables, which she sells to the local market. She has been farming for 14 years in Eldoret town, Rift Valley, Kenya, and employs two farmhands. She also earns income from the sale of eggs and chickens to the local market. Her primary challenges are fluctuations in the prices of milk, lack of enough animal feeds, insufficient water and a poor transport network.

She has requested this loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water tank. She says that for a long time, her problem has been insufficient water. This water tank will solve her water problem and she is confident that her dairy cows will produce milk evenly.

Sarah is currently running modernized dairy keeping (zero grazing or stall feeding the animals). She hopes to purchase a milking machine and a tractor that will be used to process animal feeds in the future.

Sarah is 36 years old. She is married with three school-aged children, all of whom attend school.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Food

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children. One of her children is currently in school. Mary has a business of selling food and charcoal, which she has had for two years. 

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal and food.  

With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and pay fees. In the future, Mary hopes to own a house.        

Mary is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her job skills like salon services.

loans.use: Charcoal and food

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child not yet in school.  Mariam has a business of a salon, which she has had for 2 years. She also sells shoes  

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase braids for the hair and shoes. With the help of this loan, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Mariam hopes to buy a plot and build a house. Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: braids for the hair and shoes

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a married man with eleven children, two of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, medical fees, and school fees for his children.

For over twenty years, he has operated his snake park business from home for local people and foreigners. He faces the challenge of seasonality; during holiday season (June to December) there are a number of tourists at the park while during the months of January to May, he experiences low visitor turn-out.
