Jackson hopes to educate the community on the importance of conserving animals in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase materials to renovate his snake park roof. He decided to join Yehu to save and get financial services.

loans.use: To purchase materials to renovate his snake park roof.

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty O. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Resty has a business selling food, which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Resty has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food. With the help of the loan, she hopes to generate greater profits. In the future, Resty hopes to own a salon. She is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her more job skills like poultry care.

loans.use: food to sell

loans.name: Namulanda Development Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
M. Daniel, 40, started his general store retail shop 15 years ago with savings from his much earlier poultry business. He hastens to add that he also sells milk. He earns 360,000 shillings monthly.

Daniel says his stable marital status has been of benefit in many ways. His wife, he says, has invariably made common cause with him in his plans to elevate his business. He operates in Namulanda-Kayunga. 

He says the longevity he has achieved all boils down to one factor -- hard work and prayers. Without the above he says he could not have achieved the success he now basks in. With this loan, this father of four says he wants to buy more sugar, maize flour and soft drinks for sale. Namulanda development group is his group.

loans.use: The purchase of more maize, sugar, maize flour and soft drinks

loans.name: Soun

texts.en:
Soun P., 26 years old, lives with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province. She works in a garment factory, making 2.50 USD of profit a day, while her husband operates a moto-taxi. On average, he is able to make about 5 USD a day. This family spends about 20 USD on food monthly, 6 USD on utility and 20 USD on other expenses.

Soun P. is asking for a loan of 700 USD to purchase a trailer to attach to her husband’s motorbike. A motorbike attached to a trailer can make the driver more money than a motorbike alone.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty B. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has one preschool-aged child. Betty sells clothes, which she has been doing for one year. She also raises pigs.

To help expand her business, Betty has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Betty hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Betty hopes to own a salon and build a house.

Betty is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old divorced man living alone. He has owned a metal shop for the past fifteen years. He makes aluminum designs, motors, and other metal-related work. Over the years, he has built a good business reputation, and he works closely with some metal companies. He took advantage of a first Kiva loan and has been a reliable client and paid on his scheduled date.

Today he is requesting a loan of 1200 USD from Kiva’s partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform maintenance on his metalworking machine to continue his work properly. He is looking to expand his business further in the coming year, and he is optimistic about the future.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his metalworking machine

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Khem S., age 40, makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that she buys from fishermen and earns an average of US$3 a day. She has been running her business for many years. Khem S. is the mother of three teenage children, all of whom are students in public school. The main family income is from her husband who is 36 years old and uses his car to pick up passengers for a profit. Unfortunately, his old car breaks down during operation, and his income drops. To solve this problem, Khem S. wants a loan for her husband to replace his broken car.

loans.use: To replace a broken car.

loans.name: Etienne

texts.en:
Etienne is 33 years old, married with five children who are 1, 4, 7, 9 and 12 years old.  Etienne is a self-employed businessman who owns a grinding machine in his village.  With this machine, he grinds a variety of foodstuffs such as sorghum, cassava, soy, wheat, etc.  Etienne has owned this machine for about five years and his business hours are from 7 am until late in the evening. 

Etienne needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will hopefully buy another mill which will be used somewhere else so as to create another source of income.  With this additional mill, he hopes that his daily income will increase and in addition to that, he will create another source of income.  If successful, Etienne will improve the lifestyle of his family and in addition to that, he will start saving for a better future for his family.

loans.use: buy another mill

loans.name: Tulwanirewamu Community Group 1-Kampala

texts.en:
S. Hellen, 50, is now seven years into her farming business in Naluvule-Kampala. She makes 252,000 shillings a month in profit. She also runs a retail shop. 

The combined profits from her two businesses helps her provide better for her kids. She credits her husband for giving her some of the start-up capital back then when she was more inclined to small-scale subsistence agriculture. 

With this loan, Hellen, who belongs to Tulwanirewamu group-Kampala and who is also a mother of eight, says she is going to buy more stock for her retail enterprise and she also expects to improve her farming business with manure purchases.

loans.use: The purchase of more stock for her retail shop and manure for her farms

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine K. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For five years, Josephine has had a business of selling clothes.         

To help expand her business, Josephine has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Josephine hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Josephine hopes to own a boutique.  

Josephine is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by allowing her to enjoy reading story books at the clubs.

loans.use: Clothes

loans.name: Tulwanirewamu Community Group 2-Kampala

texts.en:
Being undecided and lacking foresight in whatever you do in life is similar to a deer getting caught in the headlights -- your fate may hang in such an unpredictable balance that you may end up failing in whatever you do.

Being a product of a hardworking community, 37-year-old Hassan M. has steered clear of such a predicament. People in his community in Naluvule, Kampala, are well known sticklers fpr hard work and have always risen to the occasion when opportunities arise. 

It has been 12 years since this gentleman decided to start his retail shop. He sells a variety of general merchandise retail items that are in high favor with the people around his locality. He earns 180,000 shillings in weekly profit. Hassan also sells food. 

He was encouraged to enter this business by a close friend.  Previously he was inclined to hawking wares. With this loan, this married father of three says he is going to buy more retail items for sale. In the future, he says his profits will increase. Hassan belongs to Tulwanirewamu Community group.

loans.use: The purchase of more retail items for sale

loans.name: Loun

texts.en:
Loun S., 47, is married and lives with her six children in the Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than $1 each day, whiles her husband, pictured here, works in construction, making $2.50 each day. Three children are in school and two are employed in a garment factory. 

Loun S. is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase a motorbike for her son, who stays at home, to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
ViolaT. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Viola has had a hotel and bar business for three years. 

To help expand her business, Viola has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase food and more drinks. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Viola hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Viola hopes to expand her hotel business.    Viola is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by exercise classes during club activities.

loans.use: food and more drinks

loans.name: Suiumkan's Group

texts.en: Suiumkan K. is the leader of the group. She is 44 and divorced. She has a 16-year-old daughter. Her daughter is in college. With the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Suiumkan opened her own cafeteria. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase products in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to open her own restaurant. Klara A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 30 and married. Her husband works in construction. Together they bring up two sons. Klara is engaged cattle breeding and with money received from the loan, she wants to purchase hay for the cattle. Joldoshbek A., 32, is married. He has two children. A year ago, Joldoshbek started to provide shoe-repairing services. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase materials needed for repairing shoes. Gulmira T., 44, is married. She has four children. Her husband works in Russia. In order to make money, Gulmira breeds livestock and then resells them at a higher price. Her loan purpose is to purchase goats for breeding. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase products

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia N. is 21 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school. She lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda.  Scovia has a business of selling food and charcoal, which she has had for one year.  

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more food and charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Scovia hopes to generate greater profits allowing her to pay school fees.  In the future, Scovia hopes to expand her business.   Scovia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to be careful with her business.

loans.use: To purchase food and charcoal.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem S., 29 years old, lives with her husband and two young children in the Takeo province. She works in a garment factory, making 3 USD a day, while her husband, pictured here, operates a moto-taxi. On average, he is able to make about 5 USD a day. This family spends about 25 USD on food monthly, 6 USD on utilities and 10 USD on other expenses.

Chem S. is asking for a loan of 1200 USD to purchase a trailer to attach to her husband’s motorbike. A motorbike with a trailer attached can make more money than a motorbike alone.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer

loans.name: Pekeshe

texts.en:
Pekeshe M. is a married woman with one boy aged three years old who attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is medical bills for her child.

Pekeshe operates an open-air business cooking chapati (flat bread) to sell from her home. Her major customers are neighbors and passersby. Previously she was making dumplings to sell. Pekeshe cites seasonality as a major challenge.

With a 20,000 KES loan Pekeshe wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and 5 kilograms of beans. She decided to join Yehu because it provides sustainable financial services to low-income earners. She hopes to attend a beauty college and get the skills to open a salon in the future.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and 5 kilograms of beans

loans.name: Bwizi Fraternity Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
A determined and hard-working M. Lawrence is married with 5 children and is excited about his agriculture businesses in Bwizi, Kyenjojo.  He belongs to Bwizi Fraternity group.

He owns a banana plantation and other agricultural farms that include cattle grazing, beans and maize growing, that all generate income for the family. This has seen him earn 160,000 Ugandan shillings a month.

His main drawback has been a lack of funding to purchase more cows for the farm for fattening and manure and mulches for the other agricultural plantations, which has reduced his production and sales revenue. Therefore, this loan will help him improve his yields in terms of agro produce, thus enabling him to meet the customers’ high demand and also increasing his sales revenue, hence making him more able to meet his family's requirements in terms of tuition fees for the children’s needs and live a more self sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase cows for fattening on the farm.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem S., 39, is a professional tailor and also sell noodles, making 10 USD each day in Takeo province. She is married and has five children living at home to support. Her husband makes approximately 5 USD every day as a moto-taxi driver.

Hem S. would like a loan of 400 USD to pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To pay for her children’s education

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie N., an 18-year-old resident of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda, is single and has no children. For less than a year, she has operated a business selling fish.

To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda to purchase another retail shop. With the help of the loan, she hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own two businesses. Winnie is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to become independent.

loans.use: To purchase another retail shop

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam S. is a hard-working woman who lives in Phnom Penh City. Sam S. owns ponds in which she can grow lotus flowers. Three or four months after planting, she harvests them to sell to people who need them for ceremonies to bless the gods. Sam S. is a widow and has two children, one of whom is now married and has a new home. The other child is single. Sam S. has had great success growing lotus flowers, which is an annual process. She said that her house is getting old and it is not comfortable for her family. Sam S. will use her loan to mend her house.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31 year old single man who lives with his parents. He has been working on air conditioning and ventilation projects since 2004. This hard worker has taken advantage of a previous Kiva loan to replace and repair his work equipment. This borrower is pleased with his decision to take a loan from Ameen and feels that his previous loan amount was sufficient for his business needs. He has been a reliable borrower with consistent, on-time repayments. 

Today, this borrower is requesting to $2000 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.A.. to increase his business capitA. and purchase new air conditioners in order to continue to expand his business and increase his productivity. He expects that his business will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loans.use: to purchase new air conditioners

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Winnie Namusa is 18 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Winnie has a fish selling business, which she has had for less than a year. To help expand her business, Winnie has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase another retail shop. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Winnie hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own two businesses. Winnie is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to protect herself.

loans.use: To purchase another retail shop.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en: Cicilia G. is currently in the charcoal selling business. She sells the charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Cicilia is 42 years old and is married to a business man. She has 8 children, 4 of whom go to school. With the extra profits, Ciclia hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Mariamik

texts.en:
Mariamik A. is from the village of Metz Sepasar in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married with two children. Mariamik has a high school degree and has lived her whole life in Metz Sepasar. For the past twenty years she has been self-employed in the agriculture sector. In particular, Mariamik is involved in cattle breeding. She is pleased with the services of microfinance and wishes to expand and grow her business.

She is seeking a loan for the purchase of additional livestock. With this investment, Mariamik expects her family income to grow by thirty percent. She will invest the proceeds back into the business. Metz Sepasar has good conditions for raising cattle and other agricultural activities. Mariamik considers herself a sincere hard working person and looks forward to continuing her business.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer N. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children. All of her children are currently in school. Jenifer has a business of an electrical retail shop, which she has had for 1 year. She sells general merchandise.

To help expand her business, Jenifer has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase electrical materials. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jenifer hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees. In the future, Jenifer hopes to become a powerful business woman.

loans.use: To purchase electrical materials.

loans.name: Ofelya

texts.en:
Ofelya Davtyanlives in the Shirak region of Armenia, in the village of Haritch. She is a widow with five children – three daughters (twenty, twenty-five and thirty years old) and two sons (twenty-eight and thirty-two years old). Olfelya helps support her daughters’ families with meat and produce from her farm. She is a hardworking person with over thirty years of experience in raising livestock.

As the family is large, she wishes to save money to help with the purchase of an additional house. Ofelya is looking for a loan to purchase additional livestock. According to her business plan, she expects the investment to increase the family income by twenty percent. Since she is quite experienced in cattle breeding, she has chosen to expand her business. Ofelya considers herself fortunate to live in Haritch as she is surrounded by her family, relatives and close friends.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity T. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, tomatoes, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock more tomatoes to sell. Charity is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and 2 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 27 year old single man who lives with his parents. Despite his young age, he has gained good experience working in floor coverings for the past 8 years. In 2006, he started working independently and taking on home projects. He has a good number of clients asking for his services. This young man helps with his father with the family expenses with his income.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1100 from Kiva partner Ameen s.al. to increase his business capital and invest in purchasing a paving cutter and new tools in order to continue expansion of his business and to further increase his productivity. He expects that his business will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a paving cutter and new tools.

loans.name: Joanitah

texts.en:
Joanitah K. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is widowed and has 4 children.  Two of her children are currently in school. Joanitah has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for 1 year.         

To help expand her business, Joanitah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase charcoal. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Joanitah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Joanitah hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Ararat

texts.en:
Ararat dreams of having his eighteen year old daughter graduate from university.  She attends university in the capital city of Armenia, Yerevan.  Ararat lives in the village of Panick in the Shirak region of Armenia with his wife and three sons. Ararat is a graduate of medical college and is proud of his education.

Due to difficult economic conditions, he has been self-employed as a farmer for the past twenty years. In order to support his daughter, Ararat is looking for a loan to expand his cattle breeding business. With the purchase of additional livestock, he is expecting his family's income to increase by around twenty percent. As a life long resident of Panick, Ararat lives near his extended family and all are involved in the agriculture sector.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Heoung

texts.en: Heoung S., 39, is married and lives with her husband and five young children in Takeo province. Since 2005, she and her husband have been selling vegetables in the local market and make about US$5 of profit every day. Heoung S. would like to take out a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike to transport vegetables to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica N. is 26 years old and lives in the town of Makindye in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children. One of her children is currently in school. Monica has a business of a salon, which she has had for 4 years.         

To help expand her business, Monica has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase braids. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Monica hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Monica hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy braids.

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida lives in Lahore, which is an historic city of Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She has lived in a 2 room brick house in the area named Mughalpura with her family for the past 6 years. She is married to M. F., who is a tailor by profession. He specifically sews men's clothes and serves a good number of clients. His earnings allow him to manage the financial circle of his family.

Sajida is a very supportive lady. She supports her husband financially by selling shawls (a kind of cloth, worn over body and shoulders) to her community. Her earnings allow her to pay for the utilities expenses. Sajida has one son who is 8 years old and is studying in kindergarten. Her brother-in-law also lives with them, who has a ladies' garments shop in the market and has being doing this business for the past six years. He also contributes to the family financially from his earnings. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her brother-in-law’s business. With the loan, he will buy ladies' garments of different varieties in bulk quantity. The garments' variety will help him to sell to more customers and to earn more profits. Sajida is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has been a responsible client of Asasah, who has paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

Note: “In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Sajida”.

loans.use: To buy garments for a garments sales business.

loans.name: Esth

texts.en: Esth H. is currently in the business of selling beans, maize, and rice and is requesting a loan to stock more current goods to sell. Esth is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 2 children and 1 child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: To stock more current goods to sell.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah B. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Makindye, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children. Two of her children are currently in school. Sarah has a business of a craft shop, which she has had for 8 years. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2000.000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more craft materials.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Sarah hopes to expand more in her arts and crafts business.

loans.use: To purchase more craft materials.

loans.name: Aregnazan

texts.en:
Aregnazyan is the proud mother of four sons (eighteen, twenty-two, twenty-three and twenty-five). She was born and has always lived in the village of Shirakavan, which is in the Shirak region of Armenia. Shirakayan is a rural village and most of the residents are engaged in agricultural activities.

For the past eleven years, Aregnazan has been involved in growing vegetables and raising cattle. Aregnazan supports her extended family with the products of her farm. Her dream is to open a small bakery in Shirakavan. Aregnazan is seeking a loan to purchase additional livestock and develop her business. With this investment, she expects the family's income to increase by twenty percent. This is her first microfinance loan and she looks forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Ny P. is 24 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She sells sugar cane juice, making US$2.50 of profit a day, while her husband operates a moto-taxi. On average, he is able to make about US$4 a day. This family spends about US$50 on food monthly, US$6 on utility, and US$15 on other expenses. Ny P. is asking for a loan of US$400 to purchase a motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Cleophas

texts.en:
Cleophas K. is 42 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children. All of her children are currently in school. Cleophas has a business of a textile business, which she has had for 7 years.         

To help expand her business, Cleophas has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase materials.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Cleophas hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Cleophas hopes to own a shop and expand her business more.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en:
Hasmik H. is from the village of Vahramaberd in the Shirak region of Armenia. She previously lived it the city of Gyumri and moved to the village for the possibility to start up her own business. For the past eight years, Hasmik has been raising cattle and growing vegetables. She considers herself to be an honest hardworking person.

In addition to her small business, Hasmik is a teacher at a nearby university. The income she receives from her own business helps support the family as teacher’s salaries are quite low. Hasmik is married with twins – a boy and girl (nineteen years old).  In addition to supporting her family, Hasmik dreams of remodeling the family home. She is looking for a loan to purchase additional cattle and grow her business. She expects the family's income to increase by thirty percent with the investment.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Misbah's Group

texts.en:
Misbah is a resident of Lahore, which is the 2nd largest city of Pakistan and known for its history and culture. She owns a 2 room brick house in an area named Mughalpura and has been living in it with her family for the last 6 years. She is part of a group of four members.

She is a business woman who operates a dye (coloring) business. She dyes shawls (a kind of cloth, worn over body and shoulders) to financially support her husband. She operates this business at her home. She provides her services to her community people. They come to her to dye their shawls into different colors. This business gives her good earnings, which helps her to manage the financial circle of her family.

Her husband is a government employee on a reasonable income. She is the mother of 2 sons and a daughter. Her eldest son is studying in kindergarten in a nearby school. The others are too young to attend to school.

Misbah has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her own business. She will utilize the loan money to purchase dye colors in bulk quantity to provide better and timely services to her clients. She has been doing this business for the last 10 years, which is considered good amount of experience. She is confident that after this loan investment, her business will improve. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she responsibly paid her installments and attended every meeting. 

Note: “In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Misbah”.

loans.use: To buy colors for clothes-dye (coloring) business.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella T. is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kireka, in the Kampala south region of Uganda. She is married and has 5 children. Four of her children are currently in school. Stella has a business in agriculture (flowers), which she has had for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and quality stem flowers. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Stella hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes buy food. In the future, Stella hopes to become an expert in flowers.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and quality stem flowers.

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa K. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia, in the village of Pokr Sepasar. She is married with three children – twin sons (thirty-three years old) and a thirty-five year old daughter. Her daughter and her two children live with Larisa and her husband.

Larisa has been working as a farmer for the past twenty-five years. She is hard working and particularly knowledgeable about cattle breeding. The pastures and climatic conditions of Pokr Sepasar are quite favorable for raising cattle.

She is looking for a loan to purchase additional livestock. According to her plan, the investment will increase the family's income by twenty percent. In addition to supporting the family, she particularly wants to save money for her grandchildren’s education. She has lived her whole life in Pokr Sepasar and is surrounded by friends and relatives.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42 year old married man and has 2 children. He has been working in car sales since 2007. He has chosen this occupation because it is a good business market. His work consists of purchasing cars, repairing them, and then reselling them to make a profit. He is thankful for his business income, because he is able to provide a good life for his family, in addition to paying for his children's schooling.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to complete much needed maintenance and repair work on a car to present it in a car sales shop. He is confident that his work will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loans.use: To complete much needed maintenance and repair work on car.

loans.name: Sasat

texts.en:
Sasat P. lives in the city of Gyumri in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married with a 27-year-old son. Sasat has a high school education.

For the past five years, Sasat has been operating a retail grocery store. She dreams of renovating her family's house. Sasat is seeking a loan to purchase inventory and to expand the range of goods in her store. With the loan proceeds, she is expecting to generate a 25% increase in her business income. She explains that her store is in a great location, which makes it an ideal candidate for expansion. Sasat is pleased with microfinance services and looks forward to the expansion of her business.

loans.use: To expand her store by purchasing additional inventory

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia (pictured with the raised hand) is a 37-year-old, married woman. Her husband is M. A., and they have two daughters. Both of their daughters are in the 7th grade. They live in a two-room brick house in an area called Mughalpura, which is located in Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is the second-largest city in Pakistan, and it is famous for its history and culture.

She supports her family with her dye (coloring) clothes business. Specifically, she dyes different items of women's clothes, including shawls and shirts. She has been doing this work for over 6 years and has a good number of clients. Her husband operates a gentlemen’s beauty salon in the nearby market, where he provides services such as hair-cutting and facial treatments.

Razia has applied for a loan from a Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s salon. He explains that he will utilize the loan proceeds to purchase beauty products such as creams, scrubs, and lotions. By doing so, he will be able to serve more clients and to thereby increase his business income. Razia is hopeful that her husband’s business will continue to grow after he utilizes the loan proceeds. She is a new loan applicant and this would be her first loan from Asasah.

loans.use: To further expand her husband's business by purchasing additional beauty products

loans.name: Antasia

texts.en:
Antasia T. is 24 years old, and she is married. Her husband is a businessman. They have two children, one of whom goes to school.

Antasia is currently operating a small business venture in the food sector. Specifically, she sells cassava, yams, and carrots in her community. She is requesting a loan to stock more yams and carrots for re-sale purposes. With the expected additional profits generated by this loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional yams and carrots

loans.name: Zaven

texts.en: Zaven Sedrekyan lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the town of Artik.  He is university-educated.  Due to limited employment opportunities, for the past fifteen years he has been a self-employeed entrepreneur.  He owns a small business selling a range of clothing.  He is married with two children – a 17 year old daughter and a 19 year old son.  He supports his relatives with clothes from his store.  His dream is to have both his children graduate from university.  He considers himself an honest and hardworking person.  Zaven is seeking a loan to expand the range of clothing in his store.  With the investment he expects his family income to grow by 20 percent.  His store is in a good location and Zaven has many loyal clients.  Someday he would like to open a second shop and upon retirement leave the businesses to his children.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for his store

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita S. is optimistic that her sewing business will produce a steady income to improve her economic stability and her family’s quality of life.  Her long term dreams are to keep on supporting her children’s education and to have a successful tailoring shop someday. Nenita would like to receive a loan to purchase inventory to continue her sewing business including cotton fabrics and other materials needed in her business.  As a member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, Nenita is thankful for the access to loans to support her dreams and the encouragement. Her hard work and patience are her foundation in achieving a better life for her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase cotton fabrics and other materials needed for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To raise cattle

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna has been a hardworking farmer for the past 20 years.  She has specialized in cattle breeding and growing vegetables. Susanna is from the village of Marmashen in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Susanna enjoys living in her birthplace of Marmashen, which has a spectacular tenth-century monastery complex from the Pahlavuni Dynasty. She is married with three children – two sons (25 and 30 years old) and a daughter (31 years old).  She dreams of finishing the construction and remodeling of the family home.  Susanna is looking for a loan to purchase additional livestock.  She expects her family income to increase by 25 percent with this investment.  Susanna is pleased with microfinance services and the opportunity they allow for her 
to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in Lahore which is Pakistan’s second largest city and famous for its food and culture.  She lives there with her family in an area named Mughalpura in a two-room brick house. 

She supports her family financially with her dye clothing business. She dyes specifically women's clothing. Her husband is also involved in the same business. He operates a little dye shop in the market where he dyes men's clothing.  In this way, they both generate income for the family. They have been in this business for the last ten years and have a good number of clients by providing good quality work at reasonable rates.

Azra has three sons and two daughters. All of them are enrolled in a school and are getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for their dye clothing businesses. With the loan, the couple will buy dyes in bulk which will help them provide better quality services to their clients and increease their income.  

Azra wants to save some money to buy a motorbike for her husband and she is hopeful that she will be able to do so with the help of an increased income.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. She has maintained good credit history in previous loan years and attended every meeting.  

Note: In the photo, Azra is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy dyes in bulk for dye clothing business

loans.name: Edina

texts.en: Edina Y. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods like green vegetables and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase more tomatoes to sell.  Edina is 20 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has two children, one of whom goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Matilde Maria

texts.pt:
Matilde Maria M. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique divorciada apenas vive com os 3 netos que vão a Escola. Fez 2º nível de Educação de adultos não continuou porque mudou de residência. Vive na casa própria com os seus netos e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane quando se juntou com seu marido. Tem um negócio próprio ha mais de 8 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 2.500.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum de vez enquanto na sua casa. 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga que também é cliente da instituição. Este é o seu quinto empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, barrotes, chapas de zinco, pedra, ferro e outros) para continuar com a construção da sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 3.500.00mt, 5.200.00mt, 6.000.00mt e 8.000.00mt todos para habitação.

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo e pedir outro para concluir a sua residência e oferecer melhor conforto a seus netos.
texts.en:
Matilde Maria was born in the Namaacha District, in the Maputo Province in South Mozambique. She is divorced and lives with her 3 grandchildren. All three go to school. She completed 2nd grade in an adult literacy program but didn't continue because she changed homes. She lives in her own home with her grandchildren and doesn't support anyone else.

She left Namaacha to Boane when she moved in with her husband. She has had her own business for more than eight years. She doesn't have any employees and has an income of around 2,500 meticais per month. She spends it in household expenses and saves some every now and then in her own home. 

She has never had loans with other banks. She became familiar with Hluvuku through a friend who is also a partner of the institution. This loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticais, is her fifth. She intends to buy construction materials (cement, beams, zinc screens, stone, iron and others) to continue construction of her house. The previous loans were for 3,500, 5,200, 6,000 and 8,000 meticais, all used for housing. 

She is confident she will pay ahead of schedule and request another loan to finish her home and offer more comfort to her grandchildren.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, beams, zinc screens, stone, iron and others)

loans.name: Monday

texts.en: Monday L. is currently in the business of selling simsim, groundnut paste and beans.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of beans to sell.  Monday is 22 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has two children, one of whom goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Shagufta's Group

texts.en:
Shagufta is from Lahore which is Pakistan’s second largest city and famous for its food and culture.  She lives there in a two-room brick house with her family. She is 42 years old and is married to M. Y..  She has two sons and a daughter. 

Shagufta is a seamstress and sews clothes for orders from her neighboring clients to financially support her family.  She is very good at her art and receives orders regularly. 

Her husband is blacksmith.  He makes iron rods and sells them through his shop.  He also supplies iron rods to different building constructors. He is an expert in his work and due to his quality work, people who come to buy iron rods from him become his permanent customers.  

Shagufta’s eldest son lives in Dubai and works there as a computer operator.  Her two younger children are getting their education studying in college. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. He will utilize the loan money to purchase iron in larger quantities to make more iron rods for completing his customers' orders.  Shagufta is hopeful that this investment will be a profitable experience for her husband’s business. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she had responsibly paid her installments on time and attended every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, Shagufta is the lady who is raising her hand.

loans.use: To buy iron in larger quantities for making iron rods to sell

loans.name: Cornelio Nera

texts.pt:
Cornélio Nera M. conseguiu comprar todo o material acordado com a instituição, e também foi aplicado no proposito acordado.

Conseguiu pagar devidamente segundo o acordado e não enfrentou dificuldades, neste momento a sua obra encontra se num estagio avançado.

Com o novo empréstimo no valor de 13.000.00mt pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia e pagar o construtor) para dar um bom avanço na sua obra. 
Sente se realizado com nova mudança da sua casa e ainda obteve 2 netos, no futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua residência e confortar a sua família.
texts.en:
Cornélio Nera M. will use this loan, in the amount of 13.000.00mt, to buy more cement and sand and to pay the construction workers' wages. The work on his house is at an advanced stage. 

He used his previous loan for the same purpose and paid it back in a timely fashion. He plans to apply for more loans in the future to finalize the work on the house and make it comfortable for his family. Cornélio is excited by the birth of two of his grandchildren and the prospect of moving to the new house in the near future.

loans.use: to buy construction material (cement, sand) and pay workers' wages

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 57-year-old married man and the father of four children. He has more than 43 years of experience running a small car repair shop in his town. He is the main income provider for his family to cover the increasing costs of food, housing, and other family expenses. With his loan requested of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will increase the capital of his business and purchase new tools.  In the future, he is looking to diversify his business and open a new shop where he can buy and sell car spare parts.

loans.use: To purchase new tools

loans.name: Bibioysha

texts.ru: Холмирзоева Бибиойша проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 30 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Муж работает в правоохранительных органах. Сама Бибиойша имеет среднее образование. Она занимается шитьем и вышивкой подушек на заказ. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 2 года. Кредит берет для покупки новых материалов.
texts.en: Bibiyosha H. lives in the Yavan district.  She is 30 years old, married and has 5 children.  Her husband works in law enforcement.  Bibiyosha has a secondary education.  She is involved in sewing and pillow embroidery to-order.  She has been in this business for 2 years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of new materials.

loans.use: Purchase of new materials

loans.name: Lilias

texts.en: Lilias J. is currently in the business of selling cow peas, beans, rice, etc. and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell.  Lilias is 25 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman.  She has a child who goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Medina

texts.en:
Medina is an example of a strong woman who can thrive and make a living for her family.  A 26-year-old mother of two, Mariane and Raymart, she lives in the town of Binangonan, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. Medina’s main goal is to build a sustainable business to meet the needs of her family. She was encouraged to join ASHI, a first KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2006. The previous loans she received from ASHI were carefully invested in her sari-sari (variety) store. Since then, her business has been performing well and earning her sufficient profit. 

Medina needs working capital to help boost her business to earn increased profits. She is requesting her new loan of 20,000 PHP as additional capital for her variety store, to be used to pay for groceries for her enterprise. 

Medina is optimistic that she can achieve her dreams of providing a good life for her family and being able to bring them to into a decent way of life. Her long term-goal is for her 2 children to finish studies until completing college.  She hopes that these dreams will come true and that ASHI will
give the best direction and opportunity to her family.

loans.use: will use as additional working capital for her variety store and to be used to pay for groceries for her store.

loans.name: Maria Alberto

texts.pt:
Maria Alberto H. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casada e mãe de 4 filhos de idades entre 01 a 11 anos de idade os 2 mais velhos vão a Escola. Fez somente a 3ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras pelos progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Nunca saiu da província de Maputo, tem um negocio próprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.700.00mt por mês e com ajuda do marido que é pensionista do Ministério da Defesa conseguem poupar algum para eventuais despesas.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga que também é cliente da instituição. Este é o seu quarto empréstimo no valor de 13.800.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, pedra, ferro e outros) para construir uma dependência que servira de aluguer para incrementar a sua receita. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 8.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 12.000.00mt todos para habitação.

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo e pedir outro para construir mais dependências como forma de aumentar a sua receita.
texts.en:
Maria Alberto H. was born in the Boane district of Maputo, in Southern Mozambique. She's married and the mother of four children ages 1 to 11 (the two older ones are in school). Her studies were interrupted in 3rd Grade due to her family's financial constraints. She lives with her husband and children in a house they own; she has never left Maputo.


Maria runs a small grocery store by herself, where she sells staples, and makes about 3.700.00mt per month. With the help of her husband, who receives a monthly pension as a retiree from the Defense Ministry, she is able to regularly save some money.


She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client of the institution. This is her fourth loan with Hluvuku; she has never had loans from other banks or institutions before. Her previous loans with Hluvuku were in the amount of 8.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt and 12.000.00mt, all used for the same purpose. She plans to use this current loan to buy construction material (cement, sand, stone, iron, etc) to build a rental unit to improve their earnings. She's confident in her ability to pay back this loan ahead of schedule and plans to apply for other loans in the future, to hopefully build more rental units.

loans.use: to buy construction material (cement, sand, stones, iron, etc)

loans.name: Amarzaya

texts.en:
Amarzaya D. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and 15 year old daughter in the Tuv province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter attends a local high school while Amarzaya and her husband operate the family business. They own a small car repair business which they began in 2004. They run a small tire and car repair and car washing center. The also  sell parts, oil, tires and wheel components through their repair center. Their business has grown quickly over the years and their earnings have enabled them to purchase a building that can be used as a service center and living accommodation. They also plan to pay for their daughter's tuition fees with their earnings. In the future, they hope to expand their business and establish a larger car repair center. 

Amarzaya is a very honest, modest and hardworking person. She is requesting an 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase more lubricants and oils in wholesale quantities.

loans.use: To purchase more lubricants and oils

loans.name: Apayi

texts.en: Apayi A.  is currently in the business of selling fish  and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and some tomatoes to sell.  Apayi is 39 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Stock more fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Bonifacio Eduardo

texts.pt:
Bonifácio Eduardo M. nasceu no Distrito de Matutuine, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique casado e pai de 5 filhos já maiores de idade apenas 2 mais novos vão a Escola. Fez 6ª classe não continuou porque na altura era muito difícil ingressar a Universidade. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Matutuine para Boane, devido a guerra de desestabilização, trabalha como assistente de cabine numa empresa de transporte público ha mais de 4 anos. Tem um salario mensal de 3.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria. 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma amiga que também é cliente da instituição. Este é o seu terceiro empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, barrotes, chapas de zinco e outros) para continuar com a construção da sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt e 12.000.00mt todos para habitação.

Esta confiante que vai pagar antes do tempo e pedir outro para concluir a sua residência e oferecer melhor conforto a sua família.
texts.en:
Bonifácio Eduardo was born in the Matutuine District, in the Maputo Province in South Mozambique. He is married and the father of 5 children. Most of the children are grown, only the two youngest go to school. He went to school until 6th grade and didn't continue because at that time it was very hard to go to college. He lives in his own home with his family and doesn't support anyone else. 

He left Matutuine to go to Boane due to the civil war. He has been working as a driver's assistant at a public transportation company for more than four years. He has a monthly salary of 3,000 meticais. He spends it in household expenses and saves some in his savings account. 

He has never had loans from other banks. He became familiar with Hluvuku through a friend who is also a partner of the institution. This loan, in the amount of 12,000 meticais, is his third. He intends to buy construction materials (cement, beams, zinc screens and others) to continue construction of his home. The previous loans were for 6,000 and 12,000 meticais and were all used for housing expenses. 

He is confident that he will pay ahead of time and request another loan to finish his home and offer more comfort to his family.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, beams, zinc screens and others)

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en:
Pascal is 32 years old, married with five children who are 10, 11, 13, 15 and 16 years old.  Pascal is commonly known in the business of selling foodstuffs mainly beans, etc.  Pascal has been in this business for about three years and the business hours are from 7 am to 6 pm every day.

Pascal needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will expand his business through purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs such as rice, beans, sugar, peas, cooking oil, etc.  As these foodstuffs are highly demanded by a large number of his customers, he will hopefully earn more profits which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business for a better financial stability.

loans.use: a large quantity of foodstuffs mainly rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Monika is 43 years old and is married. Her husband  is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the business.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Linyonyi Wephukulu

texts.en:
Linyonyi M. is a 60 old landlord, charcoal dealer and green grocer in the Shanzu area of Mombasa. He has been in this business for the last thirty years. He is married and supports his grandchildren.

Linyonyi just joined KADET and he is now requesting his first loan to buy iron sheets for his rental houses and use the anticipated profits to build more rooms for renting.

Linyonyi hopes to own a large house in the future.

loans.use: To buying Iron sheets for roofing on his rental houses

loans.name: Denis Kebaso

texts.en:
Denis Kebaso M. is a twenty six year old Motor Bike spare dealer in Changamwe, Mombasa. He is a single man who has been in this business for the last one year. 

Denis joined KADET and he has currently applied for a loan which he would like to use to purchase more spare parts for resale. He hopes to use the anticipated profits to purchase a motor bike. 

In future he would like to own a matatu (public transport van).

loans.use: Buy more motorcyle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Joan Kariuki

texts.en:
Joan Kariuki N. is 29 years old and owns a retail shop in Kaloleni. She is a single lady supporting one child. She earns additional income from her secondary business, which is running a salon that she owns. Joan has been in this business for the last four years and has done great.

She has applied for her second loan with KADET, which she wants to use to purchase more inventory of beauty products and cosmetics for her salon. She will use the anticipated profits to restock the salon.

In the future she hopes to sell more in her community and train young ladies who aspire to work in a salon.

loans.use: To purchase inventory of beauty products and cosmetics

loans.name: Alex Mwachenye

texts.en:
Alex Mwachenye L. is a 49-year-old milk supplier in Tezo Karen Kilifi. He is married to Sarah Saro, who is a farmer. Both of them earn an income to support their family. They are blessed with five children. Alex has been in this business for the last year and has done great.

He joined an existing group of KADET lenders. He has applied for a loan that he will use to buy one cow. He hopes to use the anticipated profits to add another cow.

He hopes to be a commercial farmer in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Stephen Kipkosgei

texts.en:
Stephen is a 27-year-old single gentleman. He operates a mobile phone accessories shop in the center of his town. He has been in this business for five years now, and he says he earns a good profit due to the many customers who visit him.

He was introduced to Kadet Ltd. by an existing member of his group. He is requesting his second loan from Kadet. He plans to use 40,000 KES to purchase additional phone accesories for his shop.

His future plan is to own a wholesale business, supplying other retailers with phone accessories.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en:
Mouhamad is a 52-year-old married man and the father of six children. He has sold women's accessories, perfumes, makeup and socks since 1980. 

Mouhamad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy more products to improve his business and to increase his capital. His clients are tourists, friends and relatives.

It’s not the first time that Mouhamad requests a loan from Al Majmoua. He has a good payback history and he stated that the previous loan had a very good impact. He hopes to expand his business and to increase his capital, in addition to buying a store to settle down.

loans.use: To buy more products to improve his business

loans.name: Salina Jeruto

texts.en:
Salina is a 49 year old mother of five who is happily married to Paul G.. She runs a retail shop in the town center that has been in operation for 18 years. 

Salina got to know about KADET through an existing client who is a member of her group. This is her second loan and she plans to buy additional stock for her store to ensure consistent supply to her customers. Since her business is located at the center of town she has a good number of customers who are happy with her services.

Salina’s future plan is to ensure that her business is stable so that she can use her profits to educate all her children and have a car to use for transport.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her store

loans.name: Hadi

texts.en: Hadi is a 23 year old single man who has owned a restaurant since 2009. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to change the decor of his restaurant, buy a grill, and increase his merchandise. Hadi’s clients are villagers, friends, and relatives. His experience comes from working and also from completing a lot of training. Hadi hopes to expand his business and also open a new branch in the Beirut area.

loans.use: To change restaurant decor and buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 21 year old single man who lives with his mother and two brothers. This young man runs a home painting business that he established in 2005. He cooperates with his brothers to meet the needs of the family after the loss of their father. This man works hard to earn a good income. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from the Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional paints and scaffolding to expand his business. This man wants to be prepared for new projects and he plans to take on bigger projects in the coming year.

loans.use: to purchase additional paints and scaffolding

loans.name: Jescar

texts.en:
Jessica has operated a vegetable stall selling Sukuma wiki (green vegetables) and fruits for over eight years. She sells her wares to her neighbors and local restaurant operators. Jessica's primary challenge is high transport costs. She hopes to open a retail shop and a grocery in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she has requested, she wants to purchase vegetables and fruits as well as construction materials for the expansion of her vegetable stall. She decided to join Yehu because of its favorable repayments rates and good loan products.      

Jessica and her husband have one child who is still young for school. They live in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and transport costs.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fruits as well as construction materials for the expansion of her vegetable stall

loans.name: Kisoga United Group-Kayunga

texts.en: N. Christine belongs to Kisoga United Group-Kayunga. Her involvement in business began years back when she tried her hand at a poultry business that sadly is not operational any more. She used the experience and money she got out of running that business to venture into agro produce sales. She also has a commercial motorcycle business that she says is invaluable as regards the addition onto her overall profits. 160,000 shillings is what she makes in a month. With this loan, she wants to buy more agro produce for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more agro produce for resale.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda F. buys and sells different curtain and tarpaulin items. She was encouraged to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva field partner, because of the high value it places on helping women to prove their skills by lending them working capital for their businesses as micro-entrepreneurs. When she joined ASHI in 2007, she started to dream, hope, and discover a way to get herself out from under the hardship of poverty. To make a better income, Yolanda is interested in continuing and improving her business.
 
Yolanda would like to receive a loan amounting to 20,000 PHP in order to purchase a larger inventory of tarpaulins and other supplies. As a proud member of ASHI, one of the first Kiva microfinance partners in the Philippines, Yolanda is thankful to be able to obtain secured capital to support her goals in life. Her long-term goals are to build a profitable buying and selling business, send her children to college, and invest in her home. With the support of this Kiva partner, she is dedicated to expanding her business and is determined to achieve financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a larger inventory of tarpaulins and other supplies

loans.name: Fidelite Group

texts.fr: Kabene K. est  présidente du groupe Fidelite, âgée de 32 ans, veuve, mère de 5  enfants.  Son mari est  décédé depuis 2006. Tous ses enfants étudient. Elle  commença son business  avec son fond propre. Elle vend des poissons frais Tompson du fleuve et de l’océan.  Son adresse d’affaire est imprécise, elle fait le porte à porte pour intéresser les clients (activité ambulante).  Elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ vers les années 2007. Avant cette activité de vente poissons, elle vendait des souliers usagers. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner de 3 cartons de poissons Tompson  vers Kinsasa. La cliente Kabene K.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique.  Il sied de signaler que ce groupe Fidélité est  composé de 14 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en: Kabene K. is the leader of the Fidelity group. She is 32 years old, a widow, and the mother of five. Her husband passed away in 2006. All her children are in school. She launched her business with her own funds. She sells fresh Thompson’s’ surgeonfish and freshwater and ocean fish. She had a loan of $50,- from IMF Hekima around 2007. Before going into fish sales, she used to sell used shoes. This new loan will allow her to purchase three boxes of Thompson’s surgeonfish in Kinshasa. As a Hekima client, Kabene K. is appreciative of its activities to support the poor who don’t have access to traditional banking. It needs to be mentioned that the Fidelity group has 14 members, mostly women.

loans.use: Three boxes of Thompson's surgeonfish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Utamurod

texts.ru: Юсупов Утамурод проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сын на заработках в России. Сам Утамурод имеет среднее образование. Занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Кроме того он открыл магазин, где продает продукты питания. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже год. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Utamurod Y. lives in the Yavan district.  He is 48 years old, married and has 4 children.  His wife is a homemaker.  His son works in Russia. Utamurod has a secondary education.  He is involved in animal husbandry and breeds livestock at home.  Besides this, he also opened a store, where he sells food products.  He has been in this business for one year.  He is requesting this loan in order to increase product assortment.

loans.use: Increasing product assortment

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en: Chuluuntsetseg C. is a 52-year-old widow who lives with her son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her son live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her son works as an engineer at the Ulaanbaatar Institute. Chuluuntsetseg has a business purchasing vegetables from wholesale traders and selling them in a rented stall in the basement of Gam trade center. In 2005, she started selling a variety of vegetables by renting a stall at the vegetable trading section of Narantuul, the main market in the city, and has gained significant experience in her business. Chuluuntsetseg is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve more vegetables for her business in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve more vegetables

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin is a married man who lives in a rental house that has electricity but no running water. His greatest monthly expense is the cost of transporting materials from Uganda and Tanzania where he goes to purchase goods for resale in Kenya. 

Edwin has operated his tailoring and cloth selling business for over five years. He runs his business from a shop and also from his home. His major challenges include seasonality when cloth becomes scarcer at the market. 

He decided to join Yehu because of its favorable policies and low interest rates. Edwin is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Abass

texts.en: Abass is 47 years old, married and the father of two children. Abass has worked as a shirt tailor for the past 15 years. Abass is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to buy a new sewing machine which is necessary for his business. His clients are tailoring factories, friends, neighbors, and villagers. Abass hopes to expand his business by owning a factory of his own.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia A. M., age 49, sells assorted items ranging from foodstuffs to daily-use items. For example, she sells biscuits, bananas, kales, and tablecloths. She has been in this business for six years and she says that the business is profitable. She sells her wares locally. She says that her major challenge is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 10,000 to buy more buy more general items for sale, such as potatoes, eggs, and soap, in order to expand her business. She hopes to become a wholesaler in future. She is very hardworking, honest, and punctual.

Lucia's husband is a mechanic and they have seven children between the ages of 7 and 18. Her business is located at Kibera and she is served by the Kitengela branch.

loans.use: To buy more general items for sale, such as potatoes, eggs, and soap

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick, age 37, is a farmer from the town of Kitale in western Kenya. He has been farming for 17 years and employs two farmhands. His farm produces vegetables, maize, and milk, all of which he sells locally. He is mainly a horticultural farmer and depends on the income from his horticultural farm to cater to the basic needs of his family. His biggest challenges have been fluctuations in the market as well as diseases which are too costly to treat.

Patrick recently repaid his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 91,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and expand his poultry project. The increased income from the sale of milk and eggs will enable him to provide for the needs of his family and pay school fees for his children. In future, he would like to acquire a high-quality dairy cow that will increase his milk production because milk prices are now favorable for farmers.

Patrick and his wife have five children between the ages of 2 and 14. The four older children are currently attending school.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and expand his poultry project

loans.name: Kashasha Farmers Tukore Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
As it is said that determination is a key to success, this is being manifested in N. Jovilet’s abilities to run a tailoring business from Kashasha trading centre, Ibanda. The 38 year old married mother of 4 children has been running this business for over 4 years and has been able to earn 85,000 Ugandan shillings in addition to her banana sales. Her need for this loan is to be able to purchase more stock of ladies materials for making ladies' wear.

This will empower her to meet her customers’ needs with new trend styles. She is very optimistic that this will help her earn more revenue to look after her family and her children’s education expenses.

Jovilet belongs to Kashasha Farmers Tukore group, Ibanda.

loans.use: To purchase working clothes materials.

loans.name: Bahitgul

texts.en:
Bahitgul H., age 23, operates a fruit and vegetable trading business at a market called Tirlik. She started operating a meat trading business with her mother in 2004, and since that time Bahitgul has been working in the fruit and vegetable trading business. She purchases her products both from  Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city, and Taikeshken, a Chinese border town. She buys her wares at wholesale prices and resells them from her rented sales counter.  

Currently, her working capital is 2,000,000 MNT. She purchases and preserves large amounts of fruits and vegetables and sells them back during the spring months when prices for those products traditionally rise. She is a very open-minded and hard-working person and is focused on the future. Bahitgul says, “All I want is to continue operating my busiess and help my parents.” She is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a variety of fruit and vegetables at wholesale price from Taikeshken and from Ulaanbaatar. 	

Bahitgul lives with her parents and sibling in Bayn-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. Her father is retired and her mother operates a meat trading business at the Tirlik market. Her sibling attends a local kindergarten.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of fruit and vegetables to offer for sale at market

loans.name: Kalibala

texts.en: He goes by the name of Kalibala M., a 59 year old retail business man who exemplifies a refreshing sense of diligence in his everyday transactions. Getting into the retail business is not a decision he has ever lived to regret since he began 7 years ago. Kalibala has 5 children and operates in Kayunga Town. Kayunga is a growing lucrative business-friendly center that many people, especially those involved in retailing, are drawn to. M. says he is glad to bear a hand in this genre of business. His business generates him 200,000 shillings weekly. With this loan he wants to buy more general merchandise retail stock for resale.

loans.use: The purchase more general mechandise retail stock to resell.

loans.name: Rakeri

texts.en:
Rakeri C. is a married older lady with two sons aged twenty-five years old and twenty years old. Her business is located in a residential area called Pipeline and she is served by the Kitengela branch. Her business is well known by the name of Mama Mungai Food Place. She sells food such as stiff porridge, meat stew, rice, tea and other items to the local people. She has been in this business for five years and has one employee.  

She says that the business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy food items which include beans, maize, green grams (lentils) and rice to meet her customers demand. She hopes to be a supplier of food and cereals in Pipeline. She describes herself as hardworking and business-oriented.

loans.use: Beans, maize, green grams, rice

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: W. Robert is 35 years old with 3 kids. 15 years is the time he has been running and having an oversight role over his agricultural produce, beauty and bicycle spare parts businesses in Kayunga Town. Principally for agro produce, he has been selling mostly coffee. 150,000 shillings is what totals up as his weekly profits. These genres of business require lots of courage, sacrifice and determination. In Robert’s, case he has not short-changed himself in that regard. He also does some crop growing and animal husbandry. With this loan he wants to purchase more bags of coffee for resale.

loans.use: The purchase more bags of coffee to resell.

loans.name: Risolatkhon

texts.ru: Юсупова Рисолатхон проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 30 лет. Вдова, имеет одного ребенка. Образование среднее. Работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en: Risolatkhon Y. lives in the Yavan district.  She is 30 years old, a widow and has one child.  She has a secondary education and works at a dekhan farm.  Besides this, Risolatkhon is also involved in animal husbandry.  She breeds livestock at home for future resale.  She has been in this business for 3 years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock in order to increase its quantity.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en:
N. Hadijah is a native of Kayunga Town. She radiates humor, warmth and  kindliness. This good-natured mother of 7 has been running her clothes sales shop for the last 5 years in Kangulumira. It’s a business she has relied on to support her family--especially her kids, in terms of education and health care. 

Hadijah also has a rental business that she relies on to increase her income. She is quick to point out that it’s her husband who contributed most to the startup business capital account she had created. All that while she was selling pineapples. Monthly her profit returns are to the tune of 400,000 Kenyan Shillings. With this loan, she says she is going to rejuvenate her business by purchasing more new clothes for resale at her shop.

loans.use: purchasing new clothes for resale

loans.name: Nemwel

texts.en:
Nemwel is a farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. He has been farming for eight years and employs one farmhand. His main products are milk, eggs, vegetables and milk which he sells at the local market. He also earns income from his carpentry business in the same area. 

Nemwel is 47 years old. He is married with five children who are between the ages of 5 and 24. Three of his children are currently attending school.

He recently repaid his previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 52,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow.
